awd_titl_txt: Development of Controlled Palladium(0)-Catalyzed Suzuki Cross-Coupling Polymerizations
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Division of Chemistry is supporting Professor Qiao-Sheng Hu of the City University of New York-College of Staten Island to develop new approaches to preparing conjugated polymers that are difficult to synthesize by conventional methods.  Conjugated polymers have applications in fields ranging from semiconductors, sensors to opto-electronics.  In addition to advancing the fundamental knowledge of polymerization chemistry, this research aims to produce new conjugated polymers with potential application as opto-electronic materials.  As a part of the broader impacts of this project, the Hu Group is training students and graduate students with state-of-art instruments and techniques for the preparation and characterization of advanced materials. 

Professor Hu's research group seeks to exploit Pd(0)-catalyzed Suzuki cross-coupling chemistry for controlled polymerizations in the preparation of conjugated polymers/block copolymers. Controlled Pd(0)-catalyzed cross-coupling polymerizations have recently emerged as new tools for the synthesis of conjugated polymers such as poly(arylene)s and poly(aryleneethynylene)s with controlled degree of polymerization. However, limitations exist for reported controlled Pd(0)-catalyzed cross-coupling polymerizations, which include promising but less than ideal polydispersity indexes (PDIs)(~1.20 in general), limited monomer scope, e.g., mainly donor-based AB-type monomers, and difficulty to control chain end functionality. Such limitations greatly impede their applications as powerful tools for the preparation of many valuable conjugated polymers and block copolymers with controlled length, which have great potential in molecular electronics and nanotechnology as well as in fields ranging from semiconductors, sensors to optoelectronics. In this project, the specific foci are: (a) the preparation of new palladacycle-based initiators; and (b) the development of controlled Pd(0)-catalyzed Suzuki cross-coupling polymerizations of acceptor-based and donor-acceptor monomers for the preparation of AB-type and AA/BB-type polymers and block copolymers.  The resulting materials are analyzed by size exclusion chromatography, matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization-time of flight mass spectrometry, nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy and other characterization techniques.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Controlled Pd(0)/monophosphine-catalyzed Suzuki cross-coupling polymerizations was carried out in this study. Our study was based on our previously established “preferential oxidative addition” concept and our recent results that controlled Pd(0)/t-Bu3P-catalyzed cross-coupling polymerizations can be realized with both isolated and in situ generated ArPd(II)(t-Bu3P)X initiators. We reasoned that the key to realize the controlled Pd(0)/t-Bu3P-catalyzed cross-coupling polymerizations with narrow PDIs lied in whether the impurities in the initiators could be minimized or eliminated. With these guidelines in mind, we have systematically investigated series of bulky, electron-rich monophosphines as unique ligands for controlled Pd(0)-catalyzed Suzuki cross-coupling polymerizations and developed several new initiator systems, including 2-phenylaniline-based palladacycle complex/aryl bromides and tris(1-adamantyl)phosphine-coordinated acetanilide-based palladacycle complex, for controlled Pd(0)-catalyzed Suzuki cross-coupling polymerizations to access conjugated polymers with narrow PDIs and well-defined chain end groups. To obtain arylborate monomers in high purity, we have also developed catalyst systems for transition metal-catalyzed borylation reactions of readily available aryl halides/aryl tosylates with bis(pinacolato)diboron for the preparation of arylborates including aryldiborates, AA/BB-type monomers for Suzuki cross-coupling polymerizations. We have further explored the use of 2-phenylaniline-based palladacycle complex and tris(1-adamantyl)phosphine-coordinated acetanilide-based palladacycle complex as highly efficient precetalysts for room temperature Pd(0)-catalyzed Suzuki cross-coupling polymerization of AA/BB-type monomers, which represented the most efficient methods to access conjugated polymers from readily available aryl dihalides.  

Intellectual Merit: New initiators/catalysts were developed for controlled Pd(0)-catalyzed Suzuki cross-coupling polymerizations and new avenues were opened up to access conjugated polymers with desired degree of polymerization and well-defined chain end groups. Our study also greatly expanded the application scope of the already powerful cross-coupling polymerization toolbox. In addition, our understanding on the Suzuki cross-coupling polymerization furnished by this study may lead to the development of other transition metal-catalyzed cross-coupling polymerizations to access conjugated polymers, including those with controlled degree of polymerization and chain end functionalities.

Broader Impact: Ours study provided efficient access to potentially useful conjugated polymers with desired degree of polymerization and chain end functionalities. The initiators/catalysts developed in our study are expected to be useful on the preparation and study of many types of conjugated polymers. Due to the interdisciplinary nature of the research, our study also served as an excellent vehicle for training participants including graduate students, undergraduate students and high school students.

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2021
Modified by: Qiao-Sheng Hu
